turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: How are you this holiday weekend?

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I am doing alright. Just trying to get some work done, but I am procrastinating by doing this. How are you?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Very good.  We were looking to have a cookout, but it's raining, so I have a bit of time for some mturk work.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Oh. I am sorry about that. I hope it clears up soon. It's been raining here as well. So, is there anything specific we are supposed to be discussing here or just chatting about life?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Yes, I have been asked to solicit a donation to the Save the Children charity.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Oh I see. I'm the donator and you're the solicitor. So, what is the Save the Children charity?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: It's been around almost forever.  Save the Children supports nutrition, sanitation and education initiatives in the US and third world countries.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: That sounds pretty good. I don't know why I've never heard of it. Doesn't sound like a charity someone could disagree with. Have they had any scandals or any thing?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: None that I am aware of.  I'm surprised you've never heard of it.  They have run television commercials off and on for decades.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Only thing that comes to mind is UNICEF. It also has kind of a generic name, but I suppose if it's been around so long, then others copied those sorts of names from them. But that could be why it isn't strong in my memory.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Less than 10% of the money raised goes for fund raising purposes, and only 5% for management.  Over 85% goes directly to recipients.  It is one of the most efficient charities around and is highly rated by the groups that do such things.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Awesome. Well then, I guess I would like to donate. How does that work?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: You can donate the money that you are receiving for this mturk task, up to $2.  It's for a good cause.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Ahhhh. I see. Ok that wasn\'t clear to me in my instructions. Alright. So, do I just say something specific like "I would like to donate 2 dollars" or do you have to ask me a specific question?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: I suspect that end of the conversation, you will be asked to donate a specific amount.  But it can't hurt to state how much of it you would like to donate.  With me, there's something about holiday weekends that makes me feel more charitable.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Ok. I am going to donate the entire $2 then. Are you provided with any sort of incentive to make me donate more? The donation will stay the same regardless. Or are you not allowed to say?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: What I know is that the research team will collect all the money all the donations and send the money directly to Save the Children.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I feel like that is a statement they told you to say if someone asks haha. That's fine. Like I said. I will keep the donation the same, I just was curious. I am I the only person you've had to ask?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Yes, you are.  Sometimes it's hard to figure out what some of these mturk tasks are going after.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Yeah. I am wondering if they will still give me the $2 regardless, but I am not holding hope. It's okay regardless. If it's as good of an organization as it seems, then I don't mind.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: The task indicates that we can complete the conversation now.  Thank you for the donation.  I hope the rain stops where you are and you can enjoy the rest of the day.

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Great. Same to you. Enjoy the rest of the day!
